abstract.text: The objective of the present study was to investigate whether cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) is associated with malignancy, and to investigate its molecular mechanisms in human lung cancer tumor malignancy.

The present study used RNA interference (RNAi) methodology and celecoxib, a COX-2 inhibitor, to investigate the effect of COX-2 knockdown on the proliferation and invasion abilities of lung cancer cells and the molecular mechanisms involved.

Human lung adenocarcinoma A549-si10 and LTEP-A2 cells transfected with a specific small interfering RNA (A549-si10 and LTEP-A2-si10, respectively) grew more slowly compared with parental cell lines and cells transfected with pU6.
The colony formation of A549-si10 and LTEP-A2-si10 cells was also reduced.
In addition, A549-si10 and LTEP-A2-si10 cells were characterized by decreased metastatic and invasive abilities.
The proliferation and invasive potential of parental A549 and LTEP-A2 cells was inhibited following treatment with celecoxib.

In vivo, a COX-2 knockdown resulted in a decrease of proliferation and reduction of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP-2) and endothelial growth factor receptor (EGFR) expression in A549 xenografts.
In conclusion, the present study revealed that COX-2 plays a extremely important role in tumor growth, infiltration and metastasis via the regulation of VEGF, MMP-2 and EGRF expression.
Therefore, COX-2 is a potential therapeutic target for lung cancer.

body_text.text: Introduction
Lung cancer is one of the most common malignant tumors in the world.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Its incidence rate the highest of all human tumors and there are ~1.2 million novel cases each year (1).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In addition, lung cancer also has the highest mortality rate of all human cancers, with 15,600 people succumbing to the disease each year, which accounts for 19.4% of the total number of cancer-associated mortalities (1,2).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For >80% of lung cancer patients admitted to hospital, the ideal time to receive surgery and multidisciplinary radical cure has already passed (2,3).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Although the concept and means of lung cancer treatment in recent years has made considerable progress, the overall effect is not satisfactory.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: An association between carcinogenesis and chronic inflammation has long been suspected (4).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The accepted hypothesis is that chronic inflammation more often stimulates than inhibits tumor development (5)(6)(7)(8)(9).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: As a rate-limiting enzyme, cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) is involved in the conversion of arachidonic acid into prostaglandin (PG) and other bioactive lipids.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: With the exception of being involved in inflammation, COX-2 produces large amounts of PGE2 in tumor tissues (10)(11)(12)(13), and is extremely important in the development of tumors (10,(14)(15)(16)(17)(18)(19).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: COX-2 inhibitors have produced encouraging results in preventing and treating certain digestive system cancers (20)(21)(22).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The present study hypothesized that COX-2 is associated with malignant cell phenotype in lung cancer.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Therefore, the present study investigated whether silencing of COX-2 and the use of celecoxib, an inhibitor of COX-2, affects lung cancer cell proliferation and invasiveness (21,22).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The present results demonstrated that silencing of COX-2 and use of celecoxib inhibited the growth of lung cancer cells and decreased their invasive abilities.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In addition, the present results revealed that the inhibition of a malignant cell phenotype may be associated with an alteration in vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-2 and endothelial growth factor receptor (EGFR) expression.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Discussion
Recently, numerous studies have demonstrated that COX-2 is not only involved in tumorigenesis and tumor development, but also plays a role in inflammation (26)(27)(28).

body_text.text: The present study observed that silencing COX-2 lead to a reduction in EGFR expression in A549 cells.
body_text.section: A B C

body_text.text: VEGF, MMP-2 and EGFR are associated with tumor angiogenesis (52)(53)(54).
body_text.section: A B C

body_text.text: In the present study, the growth of cancer cells was slowed and the migration and invasion ability reduced following COX-2 silencing.
body_text.section: A B C

body_text.text: These phenotypic changes may have been caused by the alterations in the expression of VEGF, MMP-2 and EGFR following COX-2 silencing.
body_text.section: A B C

body_text.text: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to report the direct association between VEGF, MMP-2 and EGFR expression and COX-2 in lung cancer cells.
body_text.section: A B C

body_text.text: In conclusion, the present study revealed that COX-2 is very important in lung tumor growth, infiltration and metastasis via regulating VEGF, MMP-2 and EGFR expression.
body_text.section: A B C

body_text.text: COX-2 may be a potential target for lung cancer prevention and treatment.
